trial_identification.studytitle: The Acupause study: Acupuncture for postmenopausal hot flushes
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised sham-controlled single-blind trial of the efficacy of needle acupuncture vs sham acupuncture in reducing hot flush score in postmenopausal women

interventions.interventions: Women in the intervention group will receive ten sessions of acupuncture given twice weekly over the first two weeks then weekly for the subsequent six weeks, a total of eight weeks duration of treatment. Acupuncture will be administered by trained practitioners of Traditional Chinese medicine who have five years of more clinical experience and are registered with the Chinese Medicine Registration Board. Six acupoints will be needled at each visit (Kidney 6, Kidney 7, Spleen 6, Conception Vessel 4, Heart 6 and Liver 3). Needles will be retained for twenty minutes and manually stimulated at ten minutes. No cointerventions are allowed.
interventions.comparator: Women in the sham group will receive ten sessions of sham acupuncture according to the same schedule as the intervention group. Sham needles are blunt and do not penetrate the skin. Six non-acupuncture points will be "needled" and "retained" for twenty minutes, again with manual stimulation at ten minutes.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Hot flush score (comprising hot flush severity and frequency measures) using seven-day hot flush diaries

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life as measured by the Menopause-Specific-Quality of Life Questionnaire (MENQOL)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: End of treatment (8 weeks), 3 and 6 months post end of treatment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Hot flush score (comprising hot flush severity and frequency measures) using seven-day hot flush diaries
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 3 and 6 months post end of treatment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Expectancy and beliefs about acupuncture, and credibility of the sham control, as measured by the Credibility and Expectancy questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Immediately following the first treatment session

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Inclusion criteria will be postmenopausal women at least 12 months since final menstrual period, who have a mean hot flush score of at least 14 over a 7 day period (assessed on a validated hot flush diary and who meet the criteria for the traditional Chinese medicine diagnosis of Kidney Yin deficiency (determined by a structured Chinese Medicine history and examination. )
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Exclusion criteria include contraindications to acupuncture (anticoagulation, heart valve disease, poorly controlled diabetes mellitus); past experience of needle acupuncture in the preceding two years; hot flushes starting or worsening after surgical or chemotherapy-induced menopause or after diagnosis with or treatment of breast cancer; premature ovarian failure; endocrine or other medical disorders (uncontrolled thyroid disease, medical reasons to be amenorrheic eg uncontrolled hyperprolactinemia or Cushings syndrome); hormonal treatment prior to screening, depending on route of administration, ranging from 4 weeks for vaginal to 6 months for injectable pellets; phytoestrogen therapy in the preceeding 6 months; other treatments for hot flushes within 8 weeks of screening (including complementary medicines); unable to give informed consent or use outcome measurement tools; or unable to attend for acupuncture sessions as per protocol.

trial_design.concealment: A research assistant will randomly allocate the participants to either real or sham acupuncture using a computer generated randomisation schedule, stratified by practitioner and blocked randomised. She will inform the practitioner of group allocation by SMS or fax, depending on the practitionerâ€™s preference. The group allocation will be indicated only by the point prescription to avoid unblinding should the participant inadvertently see the fax or SMS.
trial_design.sequence: The randomisation sequence will be computer-generated

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study aims to test if acupuncture is effective in treating hot flushes after the menopause.
